description: From Old French destemprer, from Latin distemperare.

entries.meaning: (veterinary medicine, pathology) A viral disease of animals, such as dogs and cats, characterised by fever, coughing and catarrh.
(archaic) A disorder of the humours of the body; a disease.
examples: O perplex'd discomposition, O ridling distemper, O miserable condition of Man!

entries.meaning: (countable) A painting produced with this kind of paint.

verbs.description: distemper (third-person singular simple present distempers, present participle distempering, simple past and past participle distempered)

entries.meaning: To temper or mix unduly; to make disproportionate; to change the due proportions of.
To derange the functions of, whether bodily, mental, or spiritual; to disorder; to disease.
examples: The imagination, when completely distempered, is the most incurable of all disordered faculties.

entries.meaning: To deprive of temper or moderation; to disturb; to ruffle; to make disaffected, ill-humoured, or malignant.
examples: I have been long accustomed to defend you,
To heal and pacify distempered spirits.
And the Duke himselfe, (I dare not say distemperd,
But kind, and in his tottering chaire carousing)

entries.meaning: To mix (colours) in the way of distemper.
